content:
AUSTRALIA

Cromwell Property Group (CMW AT) - Shareholder ARA put bid for AUD 80mln in stock as part of AUD 375mln institutional placement to maintain its 20.6% stake in the Co. (Newswires)

GBST Holdings (GBT AT) - Bravura reportedly plan to raise offer for the Co. to AUD 3.00/Shr from AUD 2.72/Shr. (Newswires)

Mirvac (MGR AT) - Co. acquires industrial estate in Sydney for AUD 94.2mln. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. Oyu Tolgoi entered into agreements with 3 EPC contractors in China. (Newswires)

Silver Lake Resources (SLR AT) - Co. reports high-grade mineralisation was intersected in new area of focus in the Deflector South West corridor target area. (Newswires)

Sonic Healthcare (SHL AT) - Co. announces sale of stake in GLP Systems. (Newswires)

Financials - ASIC reportedly could use new powers to ban harmful products sold by financial companies. (The Australian)

Gambling - Macquarie has banned gambling and lottery transactions on its credit cards. (AFR)

 

 

JAPAN

Japan Display (6740 JT) - Apple (AAPL) is to inject USD 100mln into Japan Display and is also planning to increase its orders from the Co. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Japan’s market watchdog is likely to recommend as much as JPY 4bln fine after the Co. allegedly under reported former Chairman Ghosn’s pay. (Newswires)

NTT (9432 JT) - Co. unit will acquire Symmetry. (Newswires)

Seiyu (8268 JT) - Walmart confirms it plans to re-list its Japanese unit Seiyu. (Newswires).

Toyota (7203 JT) - 5 Japanese automakers are to join the Toyota-Softbank self-driving auto JV. (Nikkei)

Tax - Japan FY18/19 tax revenues is said to be revised higher to a record JPY 60.4tln from previous estimate of JPY 59.1tln. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe said will not hesitate to counter any economic downside risks with flexible action. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

COWAY (021240 KS) - Woongjin is planning to sell around 25.1% stake in Woongjin Coway. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. and Saudi Aramco signed MOU to partner on hydrogen ecosystem related tech. (Yonhap)

Woori Financial (053000 KS) - Woori Bank (000030 KS) is in talks to sell a stake in the Co. to a Taiwanese firm. (Newswires)

Energy - Saudi Aramco signed 12 agreements with South Korean partners valued at billions. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - South Korea President Moon states that US has proposed working level talks with North Korea, while it was also reported that US President Trump will not meet with North Korea leader Kim during his upcoming Asia trip. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea will pump KRW 70tln to nurture the services sector. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China knows what the US has to have for a trade deal and that he would do additional tariffs if there was no deal with China which could be 10% not 25%. Trump added that it is possible to reach a deal with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit and avoid the need for further tariffs but also suggested he is happy where things are now, while he later stated that his plan B with China is to reduce business with them. (Newswires/Fox Business)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the US-China trade deal is 90% complete although some later suggested that Mnuchin said we were 90% done and was speaking in the past tense. In related news, US Commerce Secretary Ross said US President Trump and Chinese President Xi will hopefully put trade talks back on track and that the US is looking for a "reasonable" trade deal with China. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor suggested that with dozens of hours left before Xi-Trump summit, Chinese state media has continued to criticize the US harshly which is a situation that never happened previously and that no Chinese official now speaks with such optimism referring to comments by US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin. (Newswires)

China's State Council said it will fine tune monetary policy in a preemptive way but keeping it prudent and will roll out measures to cut financing costs for smaller firms, as well as keep liquidity reasonably ample. The State Councill will also deepen market-based interest rate reform and improve commercial banks' lending rate pricing mechanism, while it added that financial institutions are to issue more than CNY 180bln in bonds this year to make loans to smaller firms. (Newswires)

 

EU

BoE Governor Carney said BoE forecasts do not include the no-deal Brexit risk which is baked into market interest rate forecasts and that no-deal risk has pushed down market path for rates, while he added that it is more likely they will provide stimulus than tightening after a no-deal. Carney also commented that the BoE will change its forecasts if the government's Brexit policy changes and that monetary policy has "somewhat limited abilities" to offset drag from trade tensions. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte expects to make progress on the budget deal with EU in talks with Juncker over the G20 meeting. In addition, a government source said they will cut 2019 deficit close to 2% but are unlikely to set a new 2020 target, while the source added they are to pledge to cut spending and scrap tax breaks for 2020 and will find other funding to avoid increasing sales tax. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks -12.788M vs. Exp. -2.54M (Prev. -3.106M). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said Iran’s leadership is not smart and reiterated that he hopes there is no war with Iran but also thinks that such a war would not last long. Furthermore, Trump commented that it is fine with him if there is no deal with Iran and that he has unlimited time. (Newswires/Fox)

Iran’s envoy told the UN Security Council that it will not endure the burdens of preserving the nuclear deal and stated that the deal is in a critical condition if remaining participants don't take steps to preserve it, they must accept full responsibility for any consequences. The envoy added the US offer of talks cannot be trusted as long as illegal sanctions remain in place. (Newswires)

Acting US Defence Secretary Esper warned his Turkish counterpart of consequences if Ankara acquires the Russian S-400 air defense system. (Newswires)

Libya's UN-backed government forces have retaken the town of Gharyan which is located south of Tripoli from the Eastern Forces of General Haftar. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump said other countries have devalued their currencies and the US cannot because of Fed policy, while he added that Powell is not doing a good job and does not do anything for the US as other countries devalue. Furthermore, Trump said Fed policy is "insane" and that the ECB is pouring money in whilst the Fed is taking money out, while he also commented that that he has the right to demote or fire Powell but has never suggested he would. (Fox Business News)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said signs of persistent inflation drag would be concerning and might require policy makers to do more, while she noted that it is possible inflation expectations are drifting lower. Daly also commented the US economy is strong and tighter than it has been in a while but there might be more to run and that efforts to get inflation back to target could be appropriate, while the next few weeks will provide clarity on whether or not more stimulus is needed. (Newswires)

  • US Durable Goods (May) -1.3% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -2.1%, Rev. -2.8%). (Newswires)
  • US Adv Goods Trade Balance (May) -74.55B (Prev. -70.92B)
  • US Wholesale Inventories Adv (May) 0.4% (Prev. 0.8%, Rev. 0.9%)
  • US Retail Inventories Ex-Auto Adv (May) 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%, Rev. 0.5%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Micron (MU) shares jumped higher after the co. reported strong earnings, saying it can lawfully resume shipping a certain subset of products to Huawei and said that it has mitigated 90% of China tariff impact. The positive effect from Micron helped to raise confidence in a H2 recovery for chipmakers, as such the SOX Index of semiconductors jumped higher. Notable other gainers within the index were Western Digital Corp (WDC), who received an upgrade to buy at Craig-Hallum, and Nvidia Corp (NVDA). The utilities, consumer staples and health care sectors came under pressure, trader chatter suggesting month/quarter end factors could have been at play, as well as the outperformance of “riskier” sectors such as information technology and consumer discretionary in line with wider market risk on. Chinese hackers reportedly targeted a number of major computer service providers, including IBM (IBM), HPE (HPE) and DXC (DXC). Apple (AAPL) also moved higher, buoyed by the news that the technology co had acquired Drive.ai, an autonomous driving start up. Boeing (BA) shares saw some upside on reports alleged the aircraft maker is in talks with airline customers over possible reimbursements for 737 MAX grounding. FedEx (FDX) moved as earnings beat expectations, with analysts saying earnings were “no worse than feared”. Beyond Meat (BYND) rose after the co. announced plans to roll-out a new plant-based ‘ground beef’ product across the US. Corteva (CTVA) jumped higher on the announcement of a USD 1bln share buyback programme and payed its first dividend since being spun off by DowDuPont. IHS Markit (INFO) caught a bid after the after earnings. Kinder Morgan (KMI) was supported after news emerged that the co. will be able to begin building a USD 2bln natural gas pipeline without having get the Texas energy regulator to approve its proposed route, due to a state judge ruling. Tobacco names, including Altria group (MO) and Phillip Morris (PM) were under pressure after the San Francisco City Council opted to ban e-cigarettes. General Mills (GIS) sunk after the co. reported earnings that missed on the top line and guided lower than expectations. Xcel Energy (XEL) shares were under pressure after a federal report cast doubt over the co.’s plans to replace two of its coal energy plants with wind, solar and battery storage units, called the Colorado Energy Plan. Notable shares benefitting from upgrades; ConocoPhillips (COP) upgraded at Mizuho, Western Digital Corp (WDC) upgraded at Craig-Hallum, AbbVie (ABBV) upgraded at SVB Leerink. Notable shares suffering after downgrades; Rollins Inc (ROL) downgraded at Stifel, State Street (STT) downgraded at UBS. S&P 500 -0.1% AT 2914, NASDAQ-100 0.5% AT 7627, DJIA  0% AT 26539.

The TPLEX was on the backfoot as the market digested comments made by FOMC participants on Tuesday, where there seemed to be no urgency to cut rates by a 50bps magnitude, and officials preferring to evaluate multiple factors before settling on a rate cut. There was some downside in premarket trade, with a news organisation mis-quoting US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin (the headline suggested a trade deal with China was 90% done, although Mnuchin was referring to the agreement being 90% complete before talks between US/China broke off); there was buying action that followed from players who had identified the misquote. Analysts also attributed the miss in the durable goods data to some selling, too. US President Trump’s wide-ranging interview reiterated familiar themes (and risks) and led to a few positive ticks in the TPLEX. A mediocre 5-year auction saw a tail of 0.6bps; direct bidders took the most since February, leaving dealers with the smallest share since February as well, the yield was the lowest at a 5s auction since August 2017. The US concludes the week’s supply with an auction of 7s on Thursday. The last two 7-year note auctions have tailed, the last by a chunky 1.9bps on soft cover. The latest positioning data indicates dealers were long in the 6-7 year sector to the tune of around USD 22.6bln, a higher amount than the previous auction cycle, which could be a negative for the auction. SocGen’s analysts hold a slight negative going into the auction; the bank argued that the 7-year sector was trading rich vs 5s and 10s, and is trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s. The WI yield is also trading beneath all other stop out rates since October 2016, and SocGen says concession will therefore be needed heading into the auction. US T-note futures (U9) settled 17 ticks lower at 127-19

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 26th June 2019: Markets continue to digest Fedspeak ahead of G20
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 26th June 2019: Markets continue to digest Fedspeak ahead of G20

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equites mixed, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Mnuchin says China deal was 90% complete before breakdown; Trump reiterates China tariff threat, criticises Fed again; US Durable Goods dragged down by Boeing; Iran will not preserve nuclear deal; US Crude largest draw since Sep 2016.

* COMING UP: Japan Retail Sales; NZ Business Outlook; China Industrial Profit; Saxony State CPI, Germany CPI; EU Sentiment Data; US Initial Jobless Claims; Banxico Interest Rate Decision

 

* TRUMP INTERVIEW: US President Trump, in a wide-ranging interview with Fox Business, said if there was no trade deal with China, the US will slap tariffs on the remaining USD 300bln of Chinese imports, though the President said it would be at a 10% rate, not the 25% previously floated. Trump suggested that it was possible to reach a deal with China on trade at this week’s G20, and he also confirmed remarks from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, who again stated that before talks broke off, negotiators were 90% there on a deal. There wasn’t much new on the Iran front in the interview, though the President reiterated he did not want war with the nation, but if there was any military conflict, he warned it would not last long. Trump reiterated familiar criticisms of the Fed and its Chair Powell, and also aimed at big tech names FB, GOOG, TWTR, threatening to legislate to improve competition within the sector; while also taking a swipe at Bank of America’s (BAC) research.

* TRADE WARS: Desks have been digesting Tuesday’s report that suggests that the US is willing to hold-off tariffs on the remaining USD 300bln of Chinese imports, and are prepared to resume negotiations with China. While the report is another sign of a softening of the US approach ahead of the G20, reports also state that the US is not willing to provide concessions on trade, keeping the chances of progress limited.

* IRAN: Not much in the way of easing conditions between Washington and Tehran on Wednesday, with further punchy comments from both sides. US President Trump said in a Fox Business interview that Iran’s leadership is not smart, reiterating his preference for no war, but caveating that if there was a war it would not last long. The Iranian UN Envoy said that US offers for talks cannot be trusted as long as sanctions remain in place; maybe worth highlighting that previously, Iran’s Foreign Minister Zarif said that the option of diplomacy had closed permanently. Trump later said that he is fine with there being no deal with Iran, he has unlimited time. In regard to the nuclear pact, the Iranian envoy told the UN Security Council that it will not endure the burdens of preserving the deal, and the deal is in a critical condition if remaining participants don't take steps to preserve it, warning that they must accept full responsibility for any consequences.

* US DURABLE GOODS: As was widely flagged in advance, the headline was dragged lower on the back of Boeing failing to secure any orders in May, with the headline -1.3% (consensus was looking for -0.1%). Capital Economics says that this suggests that business equipment investment was not quite as soft as had been feared in Q2: "The decline in headline orders was principally due to a 28.2% M/M fall in commercial aircraft orders, that’s bad enough, but that number, which is supposed to be net of cancellations, still doesn’t reflect the large number of order cancellations that Boeing has reported in the past couple of months." The consultancy says we should expect more declines over the summer. The core metric, meanwhile, rose 0.3%, beating expectations, and shipments of non-defence capital goods ex-aircraft, which feeds into the equipment investment component in the GDP report, increased by 0.7% M/M in May, which could signal that equipment investment growth could be closer to 5% annualised, Capital Economics says (it was previously looking for around zero).

* US GOODS TRADE BALANCE: The US goods trade deficit widened by more than was expected (USD 74.5bln vs USD 70.9bln seen in April). Total trade was up in May, with exports rising in line with imports. "Still, momentum remains subdued with exports down 2.3% Y/Y, lagging import growth of 3% Y/Y," Oxford Economics says, "the global growth soft patch and protectionist trade policies are constraining exports, while import growth is easing in line with the domestic economy in 2019."

* G20 DRAFT COMMUNIQUE: G20 leaders will call for the promotion of free trade to achieve strong global growth, as the United States and China seek to resume talks to resolve their bitter trade dispute, Japan’s Asahi reported. The statement will highlight the promotion of free trade and technological innovation as two of the key drivers of the global economy, Asahi said, it also stresses the importance for nations of the grouping to create a positive cycle so that the benefits of solid growth are distributed broadly.

* RBNZ: The RBNZ left its OCR unchanged at 1.50% as expected, albeit the statement seemingly ramped up the prospect of further OCR reductions ahead. “Given the weaker global economic outlook and the risk of ongoing subdued domestic growth, a lower OCR may be needed”, the statement noted, meanwhile the minutes showed that “members agreed that more support from monetary policy was likely to be necessary.” The dovish message appears to be driven mostly by global developments, Goldman Sachs said, citing weaker trading-partner growth, trade tensions, dovish shift by global central banks and the associated upward pressure on the NZD. The overall tone of the statement has prompted analysts to now expect cuts in at the 7th August policy meeting, with money markets now pricing in around a 75% chance of an OCR cut. “We suspect the domestic and global economic activity will continue to disappoint in 2019,” Capital Economics said, and it sees a cut in August, followed by another in November.

* BOE: Testimony that featured Governor Carney, Cunliffe, Saunders, Tenreyro didn’t provide much by way of new information, which isn’t too surprising since it was regarding the May QIR, and since then, we have had another BOE rate decision. Carney said BoE forecasts do not include the no-deal Brexit risk, which is baked into market interest rate forecasts, and no-deal risks have pushed down market path for rates; he said it was more likely the BOE would provide stimulus rather than tightening after a no-deal exit. Carney also said the BOE will change its forecasts if UK government's Brexit policy changes, and that monetary Policy has "somewhat limited abilities" to offset drag from trade tensions.

* S&P 500 -0.1% AT 2914, NASDAQ-100 0.5% AT 7627, DOW JONES  0% AT 26539. S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  0.4%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  -1.4%, S&P 500 Energy  1.5%, S&P 500 Financials  -0.2%, S&P 500 Health Care  -1.3%, S&P 500 Industrials  0.2%, S&P 500 Information Technology  1.1%, S&P 500 Materials  -0.2%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  -0.5%, S&P 500 Utilities  -2.1%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Micron (MU) shares jumped higher after the co. reported strong earnings, saying it can lawfully resume shipping a certain subset of products to Huawei and said that it has mitigated 90% of China tariff impact. The positive effect from Micron helped to raise confidence in a H2 recovery for chipmakers, as such the SOX Index of semiconductors jumped higher. Notable other gainers within the index were Western Digital Corp (WDC), who received an upgrade to buy at Craig-Hallum, and Nvidia Corp (NVDA). The utilities, consumer staples and health care sectors came under pressure, trader chatter suggesting month/quarter end factors could have been at play, as well as the outperformance of “riskier” sectors such as information technology and consumer discretionary in line with wider market risk on. Chinese hackers reportedly targeted a number of major computer service providers, including IBM (IBM), HPE (HPE) and DXC (DXC). Apple (AAPL) also moved higher, buoyed by the news that the technology co had acquired Drive.ai, an autonomous driving start up. Boeing (BA) shares saw some upside on reports alleged the aircraft maker is in talks with airline customers over possible reimbursements for 737 MAX grounding. FedEx (FDX) moved as earnings beat expectations, with analysts saying earnings were “no worse than feared”. Beyond Meat (BYND) rose after the co. announced plans to roll-out a new plant-based ‘ground beef’ product across the US. Corteva (CTVA) jumped higher on the announcement of a USD 1bln share buyback programme and payed its first dividend since being spun off by DowDuPont. IHS Markit (INFO) caught a bid after the after earnings. Kinder Morgan (KMI) was supported after news emerged that the co. will be able to begin building a USD 2bln natural gas pipeline without having get the Texas energy regulator to approve its proposed route, due to a state judge ruling. Tobacco names, including Altria group (MO) and Phillip Morris (PM) were under pressure after the San Francisco City Council opted to ban e-cigarettes. General Mills (GIS) sunk after the co. reported earnings that missed on the top line and guided lower than expectations. Xcel Energy (XEL) shares were under pressure after a federal report cast doubt over the co.’s plans to replace two of its coal energy plants with wind, solar and battery storage units, called the Colorado Energy Plan. Notable shares benefitting from upgrades; ConocoPhillips (COP) upgraded at Mizuho, Western Digital Corp (WDC) upgraded at Craig-Hallum, AbbVie (ABBV) upgraded at SVB Leerink. Notable shares suffering after downgrades; Rollins Inc (ROL) downgraded at Stifel, State Street (STT) downgraded at UBS.

* WTI (Q9) SETTLES USD 1.55 HIGHER AT USD 59.38; BRENT (Q9) SETTLES USD 1.44 HIGHER AT USD 66.49. Crude markets moved decisively higher on Wednesday on the back of some chunky drawdowns in US energy inventories. The complex was already on the front foot going into the day following the forecast beating 7.5mln bbl API reported draw in crude stocks, before being cemented by the EIA official report printing a multi year record draw of 12.8mln bbls; both the products reported surprise draws with weekly production falling again to 12.1mln BPD, and Cushing stocks drawing just shy of 2mln bbls. The EIA also reported crude exports reaching a record high of 3.8mln BPD, with imports falling by 1.2mln BPD, this echoes the narrative of US energy independence as well as a pick up in US crude demand due to the geopolitical risks associated with supply out of the Persian Gulf. Separately, the announcement that the Philadelphia gasoline refinery (which oversees a large amount of gasoline supply to the US east coast) that exploded last week is expected to close permanently has been supportive of RBOB gasoline futures, which has likely been providing support to the wider energy sector.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 17 TICKS LOWER AT 127-19: The TPLEX was on the backfoot as the market digested comments made by FOMC participants on Tuesday, where there seemed to be no urgency to cut rates by a 50bps magnitude, and officials preferring to evaluate multiple factors before settling on a rate cut. There was some downside in premarket trade, with a news organisation mis-quoting US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin (the headline suggested a trade deal with China was 90% done, although Mnuchin was referring to the agreement being 90% complete before talks between US/China broke off); there was buying action that followed from players who had identified the misquote. Analysts also attributed the miss in the durable goods data to some selling, too. US President Trump’s wide-ranging interview reiterated familiar themes (and risks) and led to a few positive ticks in the TPLEX. A mediocre 5-year auction saw a tail of 0.6bps; direct bidders took the most since February, leaving dealers with the smallest share since February as well, the yield was the lowest at a 5s auction since August 2017. The US concludes the week’s supply with an auction of 7s on Thursday. The last two 7-year note auctions have tailed, the last by a chunky 1.9bps on soft cover. The latest positioning data indicates dealers were long in the 6-7 year sector to the tune of around USD 22.6bln, a higher amount than the previous auction cycle, which could be a negative for the auction. SocGen’s analysts hold a slight negative going into the auction; the bank argued that the 7-year sector was trading rich vs 5s and 10s, and is trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s. The WI yield is also trading beneath all other stop out rates since October 2016, and SocGen says concession will therefore be needed heading into the auction.

* USD: Buck higher for a second day, as the market digests the less dovish than expected Fedspeak on Tuesday, after Fed officials on Tuesday leaned-back on the notion of an aggressive 50bps rate cut at the July meeting. Commerzbank suggests that in the medium-term, the size of the rate cut is not as important for the buck. “If for example the Fed were to cut its key rate by 25bps on 31st July but announce in no uncertain terms that a further step was to follow at the 18th September meeting, the effect would be similar to an immediate 50bps step,” Commerz argues, “but of course both alternatives would constitute a stronger signal than a ‘small’ step, not because 0.25 ppts more carry/less carry will make a big difference, but because a large step would illustrate that the Fed is in a hurry, thus increasing the likelihood that there is more to come than the market is expecting at present.” Commerzbank says the more important consideration is why the FOMC is cutting, which says more about how much more there is yet to come.

* EUR: The EUR short-squeeze has abated, helped by less-dovish-than-expected Fedspeak (per Powell and Bullard on Tuesday), some technicians thinks the 1.14 level may prove to be a short-term top ahead of the G20; the next move will likely be catalysed by the outcome of Trump/Xi talks over the weekend. EUR has today remained sub the figure. However, Credit Suisse says that after the buck strength on Tuesday, it sees FX moves as “expectations management/cleanse of short-term positioning,” and sees it as opportunistic and continues to view EURUSD and AUDUSD as the vehicles of choice, preferring to fade intermittent dollar strength (it was looking to add longs at 1.1340 & 0.6950 today), and notes that the DXY is still a long way from the re-test of the 96.65 200dma, which would invalidate its view on the EUR and AUD.

* JPY: USDJPY gains were capped overnight around 107.50, with the Nikkei 225 unable to rally following hawkish (read: ‘less dovish’) Fed commentary, while trade factors were also weighing. But in European/US trade, managed to see break above the level, though finds the air around 108.00 thin.

* AUD: Technicians note the AUD has posted seven days of higher highs, though desks caution ahead of a G20, where disappointment on the US/China front could spill over to the AUD.

* GBP: USD strength is weighing on the GBP too, but remarks made by Boris Johnson (who suggested that he could achieve a Parliamentary majority for a hard-Brexit) reminds us about the downside risks faced by the prospect of a no deal Brexit (a threat which still exists, although UK news flow has abated in recent weeks).

* CNH, CNY: Ahead of the G20, SocGen highlights that the spread between the onshore and offshore yuans is around zero, signalling a message of cautious optimism amid ample liquidity, the bank says. “The much talked about policy easing by the PBOC following the dovish shift by the Fed still has to crystallise but there no point in the central bank dispending with ammunition before the G20,” SocGen writes, “this means that a decision is likely to come as early as next week.” It also notes that domestic liquidity conditions for Chinese lenders and non-banking financial institutions are poles apart following the seizure of Baoshang Bank on fears of contagion. “The PBOC has returned to the practice of injecting large swathes of liquidity and this has squeezed the overnight repo rate for large banks to below 1.0%, a level last seen in 2009, and this is contrast to the overnight rate of 8% for the overall market.”

* EUR: The EUR short-squeeze has abated, helped by less-dovish-than-expected Fedspeak (per Powell and Bullard on Tuesday), some technicians thinks the 1.14 level may prove to be a short-term top ahead of the G20; the next move will likely be catalysed by the outcome of Trump/Xi talks over the weekend. EUR has today remained sub the figure. However, Credit Suisse says that after the buck strength on Tuesday, it sees FX moves as “expectations management/cleanse of short-term positioning,” and sees it as opportunistic and continues to view EURUSD and AUDUSD as the vehicles of choice, preferring to fade intermittent dollar strength (it was looking to add longs at 1.1340 & 0.6950 today), and notes that the DXY is still a long way from the re-test of the 96.65 200dma, which would invalidate its view on the EUR and AUD.

* JPY: USDJPY gains were capped overnight around 107.50, with the Nikkei 225 unable to rally following hawkish (read: ‘less dovish’) Fed commentary, while trade factors were also weighing. But in European/US trade, managed to see break above the level, though finds the air around 108.00 thin.

* AUD: Technicians note the AUD has posted seven days of higher highs, though desks caution ahead of a G20, where disappointment on the US/China front could spill over to the AUD.

* GBP: USD strength is weighing on the GBP too, but remarks made by Boris Johnson (who suggested that he could achieve a Parliamentary majority for a hard-Brexit) reminds us about the downside risks faced by the prospect of a no deal Brexit (a threat which still exists, although UK news flow has abated in recent weeks).

* CNH, CNY: Ahead of the G20, SocGen highlights that the spread between the onshore and offshore yuans is around zero, signalling a message of cautious optimism amid ample liquidity, the bank says. “The much talked about policy easing by the PBOC following the dovish shift by the Fed still has to crystallise but there no point in the central bank dispending with ammunition before the G20,” SocGen writes, “this means that a decision is likely to come as early as next week.” It also notes that domestic liquidity conditions for Chinese lenders and non-banking financial institutions are poles apart following the seizure of Baoshang Bank on fears of contagion. “The PBOC has returned to the practice of injecting large swathes of liquidity and this has squeezed the overnight repo rate for large banks to below 1.0%, a level last seen in 2009, and this is contrast to the overnight rate of 8% for the overall market.”

subject: US T-Note Futures (U9) settle 17 ticks lower at 127-19
analysis_details: The TPLEX was on the backfoot as the market digested comments made by FOMC participants on Tuesday, where there seemed to be no urgency to cut rates by a 50bps magnitude, and officials preferring to evaluate multiple factors before settling on a rate cut. There was some downside in premarket trade, with a news organisation mis-quoting US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin (the headline suggested a trade deal with China was 90% done, although Mnuchin was referring to the agreement being 90% complete before talks between US/China broke off); there was buying action that followed from players who had identified the misquote. Analysts also attributed the miss in the durable goods data to some selling, too. US President Trump’s wide-ranging interview reiterated familiar themes (and risks) and led to a few positive ticks in the TPLEX. A mediocre 5-year auction saw a tail of 0.6bps; direct bidders took the most since February, leaving dealers with the smallest share since February as well, the yield was the lowest at a 5s auction since August 2017. The US concludes the week’s supply with an auction of 7s on Thursday. The last two 7-year note auctions have tailed, the last by a chunky 1.9bps on soft cover. The latest positioning data indicates dealers were long in the 6-7 year sector to the tune of around USD 22.6bln, a higher amount than the previous auction cycle, which could be a negative for the auction. SocGen’s analysts hold a slight negative going into the auction; the bank argued that the 7-year sector was trading rich vs 5s and 10s, and is trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s. The WI yield is also trading beneath all other stop out rates since October 2016, and SocGen says concession will therefore be needed heading into the auction.

analysis_details: Crude markets moved decisively higher on Wednesday on the back of some chunky drawdowns in US energy inventories. The complex was already on the front foot going into the day following the forecast beating 7.5mln bbl API reported draw in crude stocks, before being cemented by the EIA official report printing a multi year record draw of 12.8mln bbls; both the products reported surprise draws with weekly production falling again to 12.1mln BPD, and Cushing stocks drawing just shy of 2mln bbls. The EIA also reported crude exports reaching a record high of 3.8mln BPD, with imports falling by 1.2mln BPD, this echoes the narrative of US energy independence as well as a pick up in US crude demand due to the geopolitical risks associated with supply out of the Persian Gulf. Separately, the announcement that the Philadelphia gasoline refinery (which oversees a large amount of gasoline supply to the US east coast) that exploded last week is expected to close permanently has been supportive of RBOB gasoline futures, which has likely been providing support to the wider energy sector.

content:

USD 72bln matures at the month-end settlement, implying USD 59bln of net cash will be raised, TD Securities says.

* 5-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen’s analysts say some concession will be needed ahead of the auction on an outright basis, since current 5-year WI yields are trading below all stop-out rates since September 2017. The banks says that from a relative value perspective, 5s have not got clear set-up ahead of the auction, and current 5s trade rich vs off the runs in asset swap, though it is slightly cheap on the curve vs 2s and 10s. SocGen says it is neutral on the auction.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Trump ups G20 stakes as Fed raises bar for 50 bp ease
content:
DXY

The index and broad Dollar rebounded a bit further from post-FOMC lows as US President Trump intimated that it is conceivable to reach a trade deal when he meets China’s Xi at the G20 on Saturday. However, the catalyst for the Greenback’s recovery came well before his interjections that included another broadside against Fed chair Powell that might well have been prompted by the latter tempering rate cut expectations and underlining a contingent approach in terms of providing more accommodation rather than overreacting to a sole (bad) economic indicator. In similar vein even 25 bp rate cut dissenter Bullard expressed opposition to a ½ pt reduction at the next policy meeting at the end of July as this would be too aggressive, but he does envisage 2 moves totalling 50bp by the end of 2019 for a soft landing. The DXY is hovering just below the top of a 96.344-156 band, with sub-forecast headline durable goods and a wider than expected trade gap perhaps capping the upside.

NZD 

The Kiwi continues to outstrip all major counterparts, with Nzd/Usd edging closer to 0.6700 again and Aud/Nzd probing under 1.0450 on arguably less dovish RBNZ nuances following a widely anticipated unchanged rate verdict overnight. To recap, an easing bias was maintained but 2 contradictory factors were highlighted alongside subdued domestic growth and downside risks to inflation and employment targets relative to the previous meeting in May.

AUD/CAD 

Also firmer vs their US peer as the Aussie consolidates gains above a confluence of key chart levels around 0.6950 and the Loonie gets an extra boost from the more pronounced recovery in crude as EIA exceeded already lofty API leads. Aud/Usd has been only single digit pips away from 0.7000 and never really in danger of being drawn to decent option expiries layered from 0.6950-40 (1.25 bn) through 0.6930-25 (1 bn) down to 0.6910 (1.1 bn). Meanwhile, Usd/Cad has pulled further away from recent 1.3200+ peaks towards 1.3125 at one stage and the NOK extended post-strong Norwegian labour report gains with the aid of oil as well, with Eur/Nok probing under 9.6550 vs a more stable Eur/SEK cross on the 10.5300 handle.

JPY/CHF

Laggards all day on a back-up and re-steepening along the US Treasury yield curve, the Yen slipped to 107.75 at worst and Franc fell to 0.9785 before both pared some losses and Usd/Jpy perhaps stalled amidst 3.4 bn expiries stretching from 107.70 to 108.10. Meanwhile, EUR/Chf was more contained around 1.1100 within a wider 1.1115-1.1075 range as the single currency meandered between 1.1382-49 against the Buck and largely inside major chart supports and mega option interest on the topside. Similarly, the Pound held comparatively tight lines as Cable found underlying buyers near wtd lows vs resistance not far above 1.2700 and Eur/Gbp straddled 0.8950, albeit with a firmer bias on no deal Brexit jitters and with little independent direction from the delayed BoE appearance at the TSC to present’s May’s QIR.

EM 

Lots of noise and breaking headlines, but little net reaction or adverse moves across the region as the Usd failed to maintain its recovery momentum as noted above. However, the Peso is now eyeing the Banxico for more direction with Usd/Mxn below 19.1350 in wake of positive comments from US President Trump on Mexico’s border control efforts.

Nomura: US equity sentiment has declined slightly, but risk appetite should stay strong
content:
• CTAs seem to have ample leeway to ramp up their buying so long as the S&P 500 remains above 2,905 (the cost of their net buying in June)
  • The flip side of this is that they have less scope for systematic selling (implying less downside for share prices) even if a break below this level by the S&P 500 were to spur them to sell off their long positions
  • Nomura have seen no conspicuous spike in hedge demand to cope with the risk of a US equity correction after the G20 meeting
  • It appears that the US bond “melt-up” is being sustained as the main category of buyer switches from speculative investors to medium- and long-term investors
  • CTAs (which have quite noticeably taken excessive long positions) are taking a wait-and-see stance for bonds.
  • CTAs continue to make gradual progress in closing out long USD positions. USD sales against European currencies such as SEK and EUR are particularly noticeable. However, CTAs have not made much headway selling off USD in pairs with commodity currencies such as AUD and NZD.

US PRESIDENT TRUMP FOX BUSINESS INTERVIEW SUMMARY
content:
*CHINA

  • Trump said China knows what the US has to have for a trade deal
  • If there is no deal with China, tariffs on the additional USD 300bln worth of Chinese goods will go up to 10% not 25% [Trump previously noted that the tariffs on additional good will be 25%]
  • A deal with China is possible at the G20 which will avert further tariffs
  • Repeated that China wants to make a trade deal more than the US, and is negotiating
  • Plan B with China is to reduce business with them
  • He is okay if tensions with China effect the oil market
  • Trump reaffirmed the message from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that US and China were previously close to a deal

*IRAN

  • Reiterated that he does not want a war with Iran, any war will not last long
  • Trump said Iran’s leadership is not smart

*FED

  • Trump noted that other countries have devalued their currencies and the US cannot because of Fed policy
  • “Powell is not doing a good job, and doesn't do anything for the US as other countries devalue”
  • Trump said he has the right to fire the Fed Chair but has never suggested it
  • “Fed policy is insane; ECB is pouring money in whilst the Fed is taking money out”

*EUROPE

  • Trump said that Europe is treating the US worse than China

*US TECH STOCKS

  • Trump stated that the US should be suing Facebook (F) and Google (GOOGL), and that “perhaps we will” [speaking in the context of the EU Antitrust lawsuits]
  • US may require some legislation in order to generate competition within the technology sector
  • Trump said that Twitter (TWTR) has blocked people from following him

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 26th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

Of note for Oil names: WTI crude futures gained after the API inventory report which showed a much larger than expected draw in headline crude inventories. Meanwhile, Exxon (XOM) Beaumont, Texas refinery (366K BPD) suffered multiple upsets due to a power loss and the largest east coast refinery in the US is expected to be closed down after a recent fire.

US President Trump said the US should be suing Facebook (FB), and Google (GOOGL), and that “perhaps we will”, in a wide-ranging interview he held on Fox Business News.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has confirmed the acquisition of autonomous driving startup Drive.ai and has also hired a number of “start-up” engineers, Axios reported.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) - Airlines and regulators are set to meet at a summit in Montreal, where they will debate the steps needed to return Boeing’s grounded 737 MAX safely to the skies.
  • Coca-Cola Company (KO) (Consumer Staples/Soft Drinks) is in talks to buy a stake in India’s largest coffee chain Café Coffee Day (CCD), reported India’s The Economic Times.
  • Intel Corp. (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors), Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) and other tech companies have reportedly found loophole methods to sell products to Huawei worth in the millions of dollars, despite the Trump administrations recent ban, according to the NYT who cited people with knowledge of sales.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) is looking to list its Japanese division Seiyu, whilst keeping a majority stake in the business.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) - Loop Capital think free one-day delivery will drive significant revenue from three sources: gross merchandise volume & revenue from additional consumers signing up for Prime memberships, subscription fees from new Prime members and gross merchandise volume & the resulting revenue from current Prime members buying more items.
  • Broadcom Inc. (AVGO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is to be investigated by EU anti-trust regulators, who allege the chipmaker used exclusivity restrictions to block rivals. Regulators reportedly intend to impose interim measures during the investigation related to the TV and modem chipset markets.
  • Comcast Corp. (CMCSA) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite) subsidiary NBC Universal announced that it has gained exclusive streaming rights for sitcom “The Office”. The show will subsequently be removed from Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) by January 2021. Elsewhere, Goldman recommended buying August USD 365 call options for USD 20.50 versus a stock reference price of USD 360.30 for strong subscriber growth.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – Executives at seven of the social media co.’s partners in its new Libra project have reportedly not yet paid to join the Libra association and have only signed non-binding agreements, reported the NYT.
  • Kraft Heinz Co (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) has brought forward the start of its new CEO Patricio to 25th June.
  • Micron Technology Inc (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) (USD) Q3 earnings adj. EPS 1.05 (Exp. 0.80), revenue 4.79 (Exp. 4.71bln), plans to cut capex in FY 2020 to improve industry supply/demand balance. The co. also said it can lawfully resume shipping a certain subset of products to Huawei, before also saying that it has mitigated 90% of China tariff impact. The co. was upgraded to a Buy at Needham, who cited limited downside risk, while Benchmark suggested that Micron’s strong results do not bode well for Western Digital (WDC) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals). Strong earnings from Micron has lifted the chipmaking sector; Nvidia Corporation (NVDA), QUALCOMM Inc. (QCOM), Advanced Micro Devices Inc (AMD) and Western Digital (WDC) all look set to open in the green.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO Musk, in a leaked email, said that the co. is close to setting a record for deliveries in Q2, reported Business Insider. Separately the electric automaker lost its head of production, Hochholdinger, at its Fremont factory, reported Electrek. Elsewhere, Wedbush analyst Dan Ives thinks the electric automaker is unlikely to hit its aggressive delivery target.

S&P 500

  • Allergan (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) was downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Mizuho, with analyst Koffler calling the recently announced AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) cash-and-stock takeover as "a hard-fought and timely exit" for shareholders, and citing concerns about weakness in Allergan's aesthetics portfolio and the company's growth challenges.
  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco), Philip Morris International (PM) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) - San Francisco City Council votes to ban JUUL and other e-cigarettes.
  • Arconic Inc. (ARNC) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) - Members of the United Steelworkers union overwhelmingly rejected a proposed agreement with Arconic Inc., after working for nearly a year without a new contract.
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) was upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Mizuho, whose analysts see the company as being among the best-positioned for the "new E&P model", after the co. took major steps to improve unit cash margins via divestitures and liquids-led unconventional growth while reducing fixed cost burdens by undertaking major debt reduction and share buybacks.
  • FedEx Corporation (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) (USD) reports Q4 earnings 5.01 (Exp. 4.89), Revenue 17.8bln (Exp. 17.8bln), sees mid-single digit EPS decline in 2020, FDX says it is unable to provide FY 2020 EPS on a GAAP basis, fiscal 2020 forecast assume moderate US growth, and no deterioration of trade tensions. FedEx announced it plans to substantially grow its e-commerce business. BMO Capital analysts reiterated an Outperform rating and its USD 190 price target, saying FedEx results were 'better than feared’.

  • IHS Markit Ltd. (INFO) (Industrials/Research & Consulting Services) (USD) Q1 19 EPS 0.71 (exp. 0.65), revenue 1.14 (exp. 1.14bln), FY19 adjusted EPS view 2.52-2.57 (exp. 2.55), backs FY19 revenue view 4.425bln-4.5bln, including total organic growth of 5%-6%.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 26th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%] were lifted from mildly negative territory by positive US-China comments
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US-China deal is 90% complete, though there was some suggestion that these comments were delivered in the past tense
  • In FX, the DXY has steadied above 96.0 post-Fed comments while the NZD leads G10 counterparts post-RBNZ
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Durable Goods, Fed’s Daly. Supply from the US.

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued following the headwinds from Wall St where stocks posted their worst performance in nearly a month as Fed speakers tempered rate cut bets. This was after Fed Chair Powell said many on the Fed see a case for more accommodation but also stressed the importance of not overreacting, and Fed’s Bullard who was the lone dovish dissenter at the last meeting, stated that he does not prefer a 50bps rate cut in July. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) weakened with Australia led lower by gold miners after a pullback in the precious metal although resilience in healthcare, materials and industrials limited the downside, while sentiment in Tokyo was also downbeat with Japan Display among the laggards in the spotlight after several other groups withdrew from the Co. bailout. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were indecisive amid further PBoC liquidity inaction and ongoing uncertainty heading into the Trump-Xi meeting at this week’s G20, with the US said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and that no broad deal is expected, although it was also reported that the US is considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports as the sides prepare to resume trade discussions. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the late losses seen in T-notes as market pricing of a 50bps Fed cut in July declined to 25% from around 43% the prior day, although the downside for Japanese bonds was cushioned by the negative risk tone and BoJ Rinban operation for JPY 775bln of JGBs concentrated in 1yr-5yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8701 (Prev. 6.8580)

China Q2 Beige Book stated that the domestic economy showed modest improvement. (Newswires)

US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the US-China trade deal is 90% complete; however some suggest Mnuchin said "we were 90% done" (speaking in the past tense). (Newswires)

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove) says he thinks 2 rate cuts by end of the year would ensure a soft landing and shift policy from slightly restrictive to slightly accommodative, while he also stated that he was approached by the Trump administration in recent months about a seat on Fed board, but said he was happy in his current job. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) commented that inflation expectations are very anchored, while Barkin added that he doesn't know if a rate cut or cuts are needed this year and that Fed policy is still modestly accommodative. (Newswires)

US administration official said USD would be less strong and the EUR would be less weak if the Fed took back rate hike from last fall, while the official added that there are many opinions in the White House about the President's authority to demote Powell but also stated that the White House has no plans to demote Fed Chair Powell. (Newswires)

US House approved USD 4.5bln in aid to address migrant surge at US-Mexico border. (Newswires)

Former US Special Counsel Mueller agreed to testify in Congress. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea said US extension of sanctions against North Korea is a direct challenge to Singapore summit agreement and an extreme act of hostility. (KCNA)

Iran's atomic energy organisation spokesman says Iran will speed up the enrichment of uranium as the deadline given to European countries ends tomorrow. (Newswires)

Russia could ramp up safety measures for its workers in Iran, according to Russian press. (Newswires)

Iran's Supreme Leader Khameni says Iran will not retreat in the face of US pressure. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BoE Governor Carney says BoE forecasts does not include the no-deal Brexit risk which is baked into market interest rate forecasts, and no-deal risk has pushed down market path for rates, more likely will provide stimulus than tightening after a no-deal

- BoE will change its forecasts if UK government's Brexit policy change and Monetary Policy has ‘somewhat limited abilities’, to offset the drag from trade tensions

German GfK Consumer Sentiment (Jul) 9.8 vs. Exp. 10.0 (Prev. 10.1). (Newswires)

Italian ISTAT Public Deficit/GDP (Q1) 4.1% (Prev. 2.0%, Rev. 1.7%)

- ISTAT states that the deficit is normally higher in Q1, and lowers later in the year due to tax returns

EQUITIES

European equities rebounded off lows [Eurostoxx 50 +0.4%] after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin sounded upbeat on US-China trade negotiations heading into this week’s G20.  Mnuchin reiterated that the deal is “90% done”, albeit US officials have previously noted that the last 10% remains the hurdle. Although some suggested that Mnuchin was speaking in the past tense. Nonetheless, this boosted bourses out of the neutral/flat territory they had been in. Sectors are mixed, with energy and material names supported by price action in oil and base metals respectively, while financials outperform as yields nursed some recent losses post-Bullard and Powell, meanwhile the latest bout of Mnuchin-sparked “risk on” also weighed on bonds. Furthermore, chip names are supported amid optimistic earnings from Micron after-market yesterday (STMicroelectronics +2.5%, AMS +4.1%, Infineon +1.2%). In terms of other individual movers, Thyssenkrupp (+7.0%) shares spiked higher at the open amid speculation that Kone (-0.1%) is readying a bid for the Co’s elevator unit. Meanwhile, Brenntag (-4.1%) rest at the foot of the Stoxx 600 amid reports that the Co. sold dual-use chemicals to Syria.

FX

USD - The DXY has forged a firmer base above 96.000, and thanks in large part to a recalibration of July FOMC easing prospects prompted by Powell and Bullard that have both cautioned against reacting too aggressively to downside growth and inflation risks. Hence, market pricing has shifted further towards 25 bp from 50 bp and the Greenback is clawing back some losses, especially against safer-havens amidst pre-G20 comments from US Treasury Security Mnuchin reiterating that 90% of the trade accord with China has been completed. The index is holding within 96.145-322 parameters, and for now at least not succumbing to bearish spot month end rebalancing requirements according to 3 if not more bank models.

NZD/AUD/CAD - The Kiwi is extending its winning run in wake of the RBNZ’s latest policy meeting and accompanying statement that reinforced guidance for lower rates, but was tempered somewhat by a balanced assessment of the economic outlook due to softer property prices vs more expansive fiscal policy. Moreover, the aforementioned latest US-China reports have sparked a broad rise in risk appetite with Nzd/Usd just topping out around 0.6680 and Aud/Usd retesting offers/resistance ahead of 0.7000. Meanwhile, the Loonie is consolidating gains made on the back of yesterday’s upbeat Canadian wholesale trade data with the aid of rebounding oil prices, with Usd/Cad hovering close to the bottom of a 1.3193-42 range and not visibly reacting to China extending its import ban to include all meat from Canada.

NOK - Another marked G10 outperformer and also fuelled by the post-API crude comeback, but deriving additional momentum from much better than forecast Norwegian jobs data, as Eur/Nok nestles around 9.6600 vs 9.7125 at one stage.

JPY/CHF - As noted above, the Yen and Franc have been undermined by less dovish Fed perceptions and revived US-China trade aspirations even though the Mnuchin ‘revelation’ is likely a statement about how things stood before talks ended in accusations of blame for reneging on pledges by both sides. Nevertheless, Usd/Jpy has nudged up over 107.50 from sub-107.00 on Tuesday and into the upper echelons of option expiries extending to 108.00-10 in decent size – see our 7.11BST post on the headline feed for full details. Similarly, Usd/Chf has rebounded to 0.9780 or thereabouts and Eur/Chf is back above 1.1100.

GBP/EUR - Sterling and the single currency are both relatively rangebound as Cable flits between 1.2705-2664 amidst BoE testimony to the TSC ostensibly on the now dated May QIR that merely underlined ongoing Brexit dependent policy guidance and Eur/Gbp pivots 0.8950. Eur/Usd has pulled back further from its modest 1.1400+ advance, but finding support ahead of 1.1350 and decent technical levels a fraction below, such as the 200 DMA and WMA. Note also, large expiry interest from 1.1370-80 (3.2 bn) and 1.1385-90 (1.8 bn) are likely to cap the headline pair.

RBNZ kept the OCR unchanged as expected and stated that a lower OCR may be needed over time, while it noted downside risks to employment as well as inflation but also sees inflation rising to 2%. RBNZ stated that the committee discussed the merits of lowering OCR at this meeting and noted risk of ongoing subdued domestic growth, while it added that risks to achieving CPI and sustainable employment objectives are tilted to the downside relative to the May statement. However, the members also noted 2 largely offsetting developments affecting the outlook for domestic growth which were softer house price inflation and additional fiscal stimulus. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Core bonds have succumbed to another bout of selling, with the latest downside pressure coming after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin reiterated that the US-China deal is 90% complete. Even though the comment did not contain any fresh news or developments, and the remaining 10% is the crux of the recent breakdown in communications, his remark has lifted hopes for the Trump-Xi G20 meet. Hence, Bunds hit fresh session lows of 172.38 (-42 ticks from highs) and USTs to 127-24 vs 128-06 at best and 128-08+ at one stage yesterday. On the periphery, and largely unresponsive to the US-China comments, BTPs dropped below the 133.0 figure on ISTAT’s Q1 deficit/GDP measure coming in at 4.1% vs. Prev. 2.0%; printing a session low of 132.97, albeit briefly as the excess was qualified by seasonal factors. Elsewhere, the delayed BoE QIR testimony has not revealed anything too fresh in terms of policy, though this isn’t unexpected given June's MPC gathering occurring last week. Looking ahead, and of note for US Treasuries comments from Fed Non-Voter Daly alongside Durables data and the second of this week’s short end supply in the form of a 41bln 5yr sale.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures have held onto most of their API-inspired gains (crude stocks -7.7mln vs. Exp. -2.5mln) with the former hovering close to the USD 59/bbl mark (having briefly breached the level to the upside) whilst the latter eyes USD 66/bbl. News-flow for the complex has been light thus far, albeit prices are also underpinned by supply-side disruptions after Exxon’s Beaumont Texas refinery (366K bpd) suffered multiple upsets due to a power loss, while Philadelphia Energy Solutions, the largest refinery in the US East coast (335K BPD), is expected to be closed down after a recent fire. Elsewhere, gold remains just above the USD 1400/oz after retreating form 6yr highs as the USD recoiled after Fed’s Bullard and Powell tempered expectations of a 50bps cut. Meanwhile, copper prices extend gains above USD 2.7/lb, now eyeing 2.75/lb as strikes in the world’s largest open-pit mine (Codelco’s Chuquicamata mine) continue, with the workers reportedly blocking roads leading to other mines. 

In other news, Philadelphia Energy Solutions is expected to close its oil refinery following the recent fire, while the refinery is the largest in the east coast of the US with a capacity of 335k bpd. (Newswires)

Barclays expects oil prices at USD 73/bbl in H2 2019, expects OPEC+ to roll over current deal and sees main oil producers maintaining close to 100% compliance in H2 2019, unless Iranian and Venezuelan situation deteriorates further. (Newswires)

subject: Russian oil output at 11.15mln BPD for June 1st-25th vs. 11.04mln June 1st-10th., according to sources
European Commission reiterates that the EU will not renegotiation the Brexit withdrawal agreement
Italian government meeting over new budget could be delayed to next week, according to sources

Elsewhere, gold remains just above the USD 1400/oz after retreating form 6yr highs as the USD recoiled after Fed’s Bullard and Powell tempered expectations of a 50bps cut. Meanwhile, copper prices extend gains above USD 2.7/lb, now eyeing 2.75/lb as strikes in the world’s largest open-pit mine (Codelco’s Chuquicamata mine) continue, with the workers reportedly blocking roads leading to other mines.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Dollar regroups as Fed reins in rate cut expectations
content:
USD

The DXY has forged a firmer base above 96.000, and thanks in large part to a recalibration of July FOMC easing prospects prompted by Powell and Bullard that have both cautioned against reacting too aggressively to downside growth and inflation risks. Hence, market pricing has shifted further towards 25 bp from 50 bp and the Greenback is clawing back some losses, especially against safer-havens amidst pre-G20 comments from US Treasury Security Mnuchin reiterating that 90% of the trade accord with China has been completed. The index is holding within 96.145-322 parameters, and for now at least not succumbing to bearish spot month end rebalancing requirements according to 3 if not more bank models.

NZD/AUD/CAD 

The Kiwi is extending its winning run in wake of the RBNZ’s latest policy meeting and accompanying statement that reinforced guidance for lower rates, but was tempered somewhat by a balanced assessment of the economic outlook due to softer property prices vs more expansive fiscal policy. Moreover, the aforementioned latest US-China reports have sparked a broad rise in risk appetite with Nzd/Usd just topping out around 0.6680 and Aud/Usd retesting offers/resistance ahead of 0.7000. Meanwhile, the Loonie is consolidating gains made on the back of yesterday’s upbeat Canadian wholesale trade data with the aid of rebounding oil prices, with Usd/Cad hovering close to the bottom of a 1.3193-42 range and not visibly reacting to China extending its import ban to include all meat from Canada.

NOK

Another marked G10 outperformer and also fuelled by the post-API crude comeback, but deriving additional momentum from much better than forecast Norwegian jobs data, as Eur/Nok nestles around 9.6600 vs 9.7125 at one stage.

JPY/CHF 

As noted above, the Yen and Franc have been undermined by less dovish Fed perceptions and revived US-China trade aspirations even though the Mnuchin ‘revelation’ is likely a statement about how things stood before talks ended in accusations of blame for reneging on pledges by both sides. Nevertheless, Usd/Jpy has nudged up over 107.50 from sub-107.00 on Tuesday and into the upper echelons of option expiries extending to 108.00-10 in decent size – see our 7.11BST post on the headline feed for full details. Similarly, Usd/Chf has rebounded to 0.9780 or thereabouts and Eur/Chf is back above 1.1100.

GBP/EUR

Sterling and the single currency are both relatively rangebound as Cable flits between 1.2705-2664 amidst BoE testimony to the TSC ostensibly on the now dated May QIR that merely underlined ongoing Brexit dependent policy guidance and Eur/Gbp pivots 0.8950. Eur/Usd has pulled back further from its modest 1.1400+ advance, but finding support ahead of 1.1350 and decent technical levels a fraction below, such as the 200 DMA and WMA. Note also, large expiry interest from 1.1370-80 (3.2 bn) and 1.1385-90 (1.8 bn) are likely to cap the headline pair.

subject: IHS Markit Ltd (INFO) Q1 19 (USD): EPS 0.71 (exp. 0.65), Revenue 1.14 (exp. 1.14bln)
Fixed Income: Mnuchin compounds Fed induced selling
content: Core bonds have succumbed to another bout of selling, with the latest downside pressure coming after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin reiterated that the US-China deal is 90% complete. Even though the comment did not contain any fresh news or developments, and the remaining 10% is the crux of the recent breakdown in communications, his remark has lifted hopes for the Trump-Xi G20 meet. Hence, Bunds hit fresh session lows of 172.38 (-42 ticks from highs) and USTs to 127-24 vs 128-06 at best and 128-08+ at one stage yesterday. On the periphery, and largely unresponsive to the US-China comments, BTPs dropped below the 133.0 figure on ISTAT’s Q1 deficit/GDP measure coming in at 4.1% vs. Prev. 2.0%; printing a session low of 132.97, albeit briefly as the excess was qualified by seasonal factors. Elsewhere, the delayed BoE QIR testimony has not revealed anything too fresh in terms of policy, though this isn’t unexpected given June's MPC gathering occurring last week. Looking ahead, and of note for US Treasuries comments from Fed Non-Voter Daly alongside Durables data and the second of this week’s short end supply in the form of a 41bln 5yr sale.

Similarly, the STIR strip has pared some of its mainly Fed-induced dovish momentum and the curve is re-steepening with 3 month contracts ranging between +0.5 to -2 ticks. However, the pull-back in core debt has been relatively measured and limited again as the 10 year German benchmark rebounds from a 172.60 low to 172.82 at best vs an opening print of 172.76 and Tuesday’s 172.88 close, which was just 4 ticks shy of the new contract high. Ahead, ECB’s Mersch is scheduled to speak, but Italy’s Q1 deficit from ISTAT could be more pivotal as BTPs meander between 133.31-49 compared to yesterday’s 133.52 settlement.

ASIA

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were indecisive amid further PBoC liquidity inaction and ongoing uncertainty heading into the Trump-Xi meeting at this week’s G20, with the US said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and that no broad deal is expected, although it was also reported that the US is considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports as the sides prepare to resume trade discussions.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 26th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are somewhat subdued after Fed speakers tempered the prospect/magnitude of rate cuts
  • US is reportedly considering suspending the next round of tariffs as US-China prepare for trade negotiations to resume
  • RBNZ left rates unchanged but noted downside risks to employment & inflation; adding that a lower rate may be needed over time
  • Looking ahead highlights include, German GfK, US Durable Goods, ECB’s Mersch, BoE’s Carney, Cunliffe, Tenreyro & Saunders, Fed’s Daly. Supply from the US.

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued following the headwinds from Wall St where stocks posted their worst performance in nearly a month as Fed speakers tempered rate cut bets. This was after Fed Chair Powell said many on the Fed see a case for more accommodation but also stressed the importance of not overreacting, and Fed’s Bullard who was the lone dovish dissenter at the last meeting, stated that he does not prefer a 50bps rate cut in July. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) weakened with Australia led lower by gold miners after a pullback in the precious metal although resilience in healthcare, materials and industrials limited the downside, while sentiment in Tokyo was also downbeat with Japan Display among the laggards in the spotlight after several other groups withdrew from the Co. bailout. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were indecisive amid further PBoC liquidity inaction and ongoing uncertainty heading into the Trump-Xi meeting at this week’s G20, with the US said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and that no broad deal is expected, although it was also reported that the US is considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports as the sides prepare to resume trade discussions. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the late losses seen in T-notes as market pricing of a 50bps Fed cut in July declined to 25% from around 43% the prior day, although the downside for Japanese bonds was cushioned by the negative risk tone and BoJ Rinban operation for JPY 775bln of JGBs concentrated in 1yr-5yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8701 (Prev. 6.8580)

US is reportedly considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports while US and China prepare to resume trade negotiations, according to sources familiar with the plans. (Newswires)

US administration official said the goal for US-China G20 talks is to reopen trade negotiations and that it is possible that the sides could agree on no new tariffs as a goodwill gesture, but it is unclear if that will happen. Furthermore, the US is said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and no broad deal is expected, while the official also noted that China's Vice Premier Liu He is still leading the Chinese trade delegation, although new names including possible "hard-liners" may also be in the running. (Newswires)

China Q2 Beige Book stated that the domestic economy showed modest improvement. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB suggested an amendment to League's law proposal on Italy's gold reserves in which it asked the League to remove the reference to Bank of Italy holding gold as an "exclusive title of deposit” and asked Italy to consult with Bank of Italy if it plans to continue with the bill to ensure its independence is respected, while it made no objection to thrust of the League's law proposal to clarify that the Bank of Italy's gold belongs to the state. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was firmer as it sustained the Fed-induced gains, in particular from comments made by dovish dissenter Bullard who distanced himself from the notion of a 50bps cut in July which he suggested would be ‘overdone’. This helped the DXY snap a 4-day losing streak and pressured its major counterparts across the pond with EUR/USD subdued near 1.1350 and which saw GBP/USD give up the 1.2700 handle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was spurred by the strength of the greenback and approached the 107.50 level where there are a cluster of nearby large option expiries for today’s New York cut, and antipodeans were resilient overnight with AUD/USD kept afloat by multiple DMA levels near 0.6950. NZD/USD was initially pressured in a knee-jerk reaction to the RBNZ rate decision where the OCR was maintained at 1.50% as expected and the central bank stated that lower rates may be needed over time. However, NZD/USD then recouped the losses after the dust settled as members also noted 2 largely offsetting developments affecting the domestic growth outlook which were softer house price inflation and additional fiscal stimulus.

RBNZ kept the OCR unchanged as expected and stated that a lower OCR may be needed over time, while it noted downside risks to employment as well as inflation but also sees inflation rising to 2%. RBNZ stated that the committee discussed the merits of lowering OCR at this meeting and noted risk of ongoing subdued domestic growth, while it added that risks to achieving CPI and sustainable employment objectives are tilted to the downside relative to the May statement. However, the members also noted 2 largely offsetting developments affecting the outlook for domestic growth which were softer house price inflation and additional fiscal stimulus. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures higher on the session and back above the USD 59.00/bbl level after the API inventory report which showed a much larger than expected draw in headline crude inventories and bullish figures across the components of the release. In terms of the US supply side, Exxon Beaumont, Texas refinery (366k bpd) suffered multiple upsets due to a power loss and the largest east coast refinery in the US is expected to be closed down after a recent fire. Elsewhere, gold prices were heavily pressured as the greenback strengthened after Fed rate cut bets were tempered, while copper was lacklustre due to the risk averse tone and amid weakness in Chinese iron ore prices.

API Weekly Energy Inventories Crude -7.55mln vs. Exp. -2.5mln (Prev. -0.8mln). (Newswires)

Exxon Mobil reported multiple upsets due to a loss of power at its Beaumont, Texas refinery. In other news, Philadelphia Energy Solutions is expected to close its oil refinery following the recent fire, while the refinery is the largest in the east coast of the US with a capacity of 335k bpd. (Newswires) 

GEOPOLITICS

US Acting Defence Secretary Esper said the US wants to get on a diplomatic path with Iran and that Iran needs to be held accountable for its actions, while he hopes all allies support any range of activities to deter conflict with Iran. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani said Iran is not seeking a war with the US but added that its armed forces will react decisively and conclusively to any US incursions into their air space. Furthermore, there were also comments from the Deputy Foreign Minister that the country has no reason left to carry out its nuclear deal commitments unilaterally, while a government spokesperson said that sanctioning Iran's Supreme Leader is an attack against the nation. (Newswires)

North Korea said US extension of sanctions against North Korea is a direct challenge to Singapore summit agreement and an extreme act of hostility. (KCNA)

US

Yields were lower by 0-3bps across the curve. Attention in early trade was on the 10-year yield, which once again breached 2% to the downside around the cash equity open, as well as the negative US 2-year swap spread, which saw a negative reaction in stocks too; the data slate helped support the complex. Later in the session, Fed’s Bullard leaned back in the notion of a 50bps rate cut in July. Powell’s comments were balanced, but the Fed Chair offered little to suggest a 50bps rate cut was coming, instead Powell choosing to adopt a more circumspect approach. The US 2-year auction was solid, stopping through the screens, while cover was above recent averages. There was little of note in the bidder breakdown. US T-note futures (U9) settled 6 ticks higher at 128-04.

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said many on the Fed see a case for more accommodation but don't want to overreact to single data points, while he noted that rates are low and are likely to remain so. Powell also suggested that in a general matter, it is better to act pre-emptively and not let any economic downturns gain steam, while he sees the market’s tepid inflation expectations as a reason for lowering rates but also repeated it is important for the FOMC not to overreact. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove) said he does not prefer a 50bps rate cut in July and stated that he voted for a rate cut at the last meeting since inflation is running below target and inflation expectations are deteriorating. Bullard added that by not cutting, the Fed has put higher probability on the July meeting and that he does not like that tactic as he suggested that if the conditions are right today, you should move today. Furthermore, Bullard said that a 50bps cut would be ‘overdone’ but doesn’t want to prejudge the meeting and that he thinks 2 rate cuts by end of the year would ensure a soft landing and shift policy from slightly restrictive to slightly accommodative, while he also stated that he was approached by the Trump administration in recent months about a seat on Fed board, but said he was happy in his current job. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) said there are risks the US could talk itself into a recession although he doesn’t see any signs this is happening yet and commented that inflation expectations are very anchored, while Barkin added that he doesn't know if a rate cut or cuts are needed this year and that Fed policy is still modestly accommodative. (Newswires)

US administration official said USD would be less strong and the EUR would be less weak if the Fed took back rate hike from last fall, while the official added that there are many opinions in the White House about the President's authority to demote Powell but also stated that the White House has no plans to demote Fed Chair Powell. (Newswires)

content: Asia equity markets were mostly subdued following the headwinds from Wall St where stocks posted their worst performance in nearly a month as Fed speakers tempered rate cut bets. This was after Fed Chair Powell said many on the Fed see a case for more accommodation but also stressed the importance of not overreacting, and Fed’s Bullard who was the lone dovish dissenter at the last meeting, stated that he does not prefer a 50bps rate cut in July. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) weakened with Australia led lower by gold miners after a pullback in the precious metal although resilience in healthcare, materials and industrials limited the downside, while sentiment in Tokyo was also downbeat with Japan Display among the laggards in the spotlight after several other groups withdrew from the Co. bailout. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were indecisive amid further PBoC liquidity inaction and ongoing uncertainty heading into the Trump-Xi meeting at this week’s G20, with the US said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and that no broad deal is expected, although it was also reported that the US is considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports as the sides prepare to resume trade discussions. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the late losses seen in T-notes as market pricing of a 50bps Fed cut in July declined to 25% from around 43% the prior day, although the downside for Japanese bonds was cushioned by the negative risk tone and BoJ Rinban operation for JPY 775bln of JGBs concentrated in 1yr-5yr maturities.
