ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly subdued after Fed speakers temper rate cut bets
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly subdued following the headwinds from Wall St where stocks posted their worst performance in nearly a month as Fed speakers tempered rate cut bets. This was after Fed Chair Powell said many on the Fed see a case for more accommodation but also stressed the importance of not overreacting, and Fed’s Bullard who was the lone dovish dissenter at the last meeting, stated that he does not prefer a 50bps rate cut in July. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are weaker with Australia led lower by gold miners after a pullback in the precious metal although resilience in healthcare, materials and industrials has limited the downside, while sentiment in Tokyo is also downbeat with Japan Display among the laggards in the spotlight after several other groups withdrew from the Co. bailout. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are choppy amid further PBoC liquidity inaction and ongoing uncertainty heading into the Trump-Xi meeting at this week’s G20, with the US said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and that no broad deal is expected, although it was also reported that the US is considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports as the sides prepare to resume trade discussions.

In FX markets, the greenback is firmer as it sustains the Fed-induced gains, in particular from comments made by dovish dissenter Bullard who distanced himself from the notion of a 50bps cut in July which he suggested would be ‘overdone’. This helped the DXY snap a 4-day losing streak and pressured its major counterparts across the pond with EUR/USD subdued near 1.1350 and which saw GBP/USD give up the 1.2700 handle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was spurred by the strength of the greenback and approaches the 107.50 level where there are a cluster of nearby large option expiries for today’s New York cut, and antipodeans are resilient overnight with AUD/USD kept afloat by multiple DMA levels near 0.6950. NZD/USD was initially pressured in a knee-jerk reaction to the RBNZ rate decision where the OCR was maintained at 1.50% as expected and the central bank stated that lower rates may be needed over time. However, NZD/USD then recouped the losses after the dust settled as members also noted 2 largely offsetting developments affecting the domestic growth outlook which were softer house price inflation and additional fiscal stimulus.

Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the losses seen in T-notes as market pricing of a 50bps Fed cut in July declined to 25% from around 43% the prior day, although the downside for Japanese bonds was cushioned amid the negative risk tone in Japan and BoJ presence for JPY 775bln of JGBs concentrated in 1yr-5yr maturities.

Preview: RBNZ expected to keep OCR at 1.50% in decision scheduled for 0300BST/2100CDT/1000HKT
content:
The RBNZ is expected to keep the Official Cash Rate unchanged at 1.50% when it announces its latest monetary policy decision on Wednesday with markets pricing in over 72% probability for the OCR to be maintained and less than a 28% chance for a 25bps cut. In addition, one major newswire survey showed all economists surveyed were in complete accord regarding forecasts for no change in rates.

Expectations for a hold follows the unanimous decision to cut rates by 25bps at the last meeting which was the first to be determined under the 7-member Monetary Policy Committee. Therefore, given the proximity of the cut, it is more likely that the central bank will prefer a wait and see approach till the full impact of its prior action is known. More importantly, RBNZ Governor Orr explicitly stated at the MPS press conference that he thinks the RBNZ are in a good position to observe data and the outlook seems more balanced looking ahead than before the cut.

Other central bank officials have also dampened prospects of a back-to-back cut as RBNZ Deputy Governor Bascand recently stated they are observing data and the budget to assess if a 2nd rate cut is required, while Assistant Governor Hawkesby noted that the RBNZ's central view is for interest rates to remain broadly around current levels for the foreseeable future.

The recent data also suggests a lack of urgency for further policy loosening as Q1 GDP Y/Y topped estimates at 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.3%, Rev. 2.5%) and although the Q/Q reading was just inline at 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%), the other components of the GDP release such as Annual Average and Expenditure were better than expected. The latest trade figures were also encouraging as Trade Balance, Export and Imports for May all surpassed forecasts.

The announcement is due at 0300BST/2100CDT/1000HKT and aside from the actual rate decision, focus will quickly turn to the Monetary Policy Statement for clues on the future path of rates and if the central bank reaffirms or deviates from the view regarding a more balanced outlook. Furthermore, any comments that support the current pricing in of a cut in August are likely to weigh on NZD, while a lack thereof could trigger a paring of dovish bets and boost the currency.

Recent calls 

  • Bank of New Zealand expects RBNZ to cut rates at the August meeting.
  • Westpac also forecasts RBNZ to cut rates in August.
  • JPMorgan sees RBNZ lowering rates to as low as 1.00% this year.

Trade
